items.author: Robert Wilonsky
items.content: As giddy and antic as any great Warner Bros. cartoon of the 1930s and '40s -- it bears seeing more than once, if only to allow for the sight gags that play second fiddle to the plot, a rarity in animation -- but also resonant and real. In other words, it's the perfect movie.

items.author: David Ansen
items.content: A terrific piece of work: smart, inventive and executed with state-of-the-art finesse.

items.author: Lawrence Toppman
items.content: It comes from Pixar, the animation studio that scored with the "Toy Story" series and "A Bug's Life," and it has more zip and a tad less soul than those predecessors.

items.author: Mark Caro
items.content: The climax, featuring what's essentially a suspended roller coaster of closet doors, is as thrilling as it is imaginative.

items.author: William Arnold
items.content: Not quite up to the exalted level of the two predecessors ("Toy Story" and "Toy Story 2"), be assured it's still the most eye-popping and thoroughly entertaining animated film to come down the pike so far this year.

items.author: Michael Dequina
items.content: Confirms that despite all the technical tools at their disposal, one thing counts head and shoulders above razzle-dazzle eye candy (or anything else, for that matter): the story and characters, and Monsters, Inc. introduces worthy additions to the Pixar pantheon.

items.author: Jack Mathews
items.content: Rarely does an animated character merge as perfectly with the persona of the actor providing his voice as the star of Monsters, Inc. does with John Goodman.

items.author: Shawn Levy
items.content: It's a good movie, mind you, with great bits in it, but it still falls short of rapture.

items.author: Kenneth Turan
items.content: Though it has its charms, Monsters, Inc. does not measure up. As a childhood entertainment it is certainly fine, but Pixar's celebrated lure for adults is largely absent.

items.author: Michael Atkinson
items.content: But Monsters, Inc. -- directed by Pixar soldier Pete Docter, not by master digital comic John Lasseter -- turns out to be stingy on context, commentary, and the prism-ing view of pop culture that made the earlier films mint.
